title: How to Use the ESP32 Web Flasher
description: Learn how to flash firmware to your ESP32 or ESP8266 directly from your browser using the built-in flasher tool.
author: SanjuOS Dev
content:
# How to Use the ESP32 Web Flasher

Welcome to the official guide for using the **ESP32 Web Flasher** on SanjuOS. This tool leverages the **Web Serial API** to allow you to communicate with your microcontrollers directly from your browser—no local drivers or Python environments required!

## Prerequisites

- A device with **Chrome** or **Edge** browser (Web Serial support is mandatory).
- A high-quality USB Data cable.
- Your ESP32 or ESP8266 development board.
- Firmware files in `.bin` format.

## Step-by-Step Guide

### 1. Connect your Device
Plug your ESP32 into your computer. Open the **ESP Flasher** app from the SanjuOS desktop. 

### 2. Configure Connection
Select your preferred **Baud Rate** (115200 is standard and recommended for most boards). Click the **Connect ESP32** button. A browser popup will appear—select the serial port corresponding to your device (usually labeled as CP210x or CH340).

### 3. Upload Firmware
Once connected, you'll see a 'Connected' status. Click on the upload area to select one or more `.bin` files. You can specify the flash address for each file (e.g., `0x1000` for common applications).

### 4. Flash!
Click **Flash Firmware**. You can monitor the progress in the real-time console at the bottom. Once finished, the tool will automatically perform a hard reset to boot your new firmware.

![Interface Preview](/blog/flasher-interface.png)

## Conclusion

Flashing IoT devices has never been easier. Stay tuned for more tools coming to SanjuOS!

title: ESP32 Flasher Troubleshooting Guide
description: Encountering connection issues or timing errors? This guide covers the most common flashing problems and their solutions.
author: SanjuOS Dev
content:
# ESP32 Flasher Troubleshooting

Sometimes, hardware communication can be tricky. If you're having trouble connecting to your ESP32, follow these common troubleshooting steps.

## 1. Entering Bootloader Mode

If the tool fails to connect with a 'Failed to connect' error, you likely need to put your ESP32 into **Bootloader Mode** manually:

1. Hold down the **BOOT** button on your board.
2. Quickly press and release the **EN** (or **RST**) button.
3. Release the **BOOT** button.
4. Try clicking **Connect** again.

![Bootloader Instructions](/blog/bootloader.png)

## 2. Browser Compatibility

Ensure you are using a **Chromium-based browser**. Firefox and Safari currently do not support the Web Serial API. Look for the 'Web Serial API not supported' warning in the app header.

## 3. Cable & Port Issues

- **Power-only cables**: Many cheap micro-USB cables only provide power. Ensure you are using a **Data cable**.
- **Driver Issues**: On Windows, you might need drivers for the USB-to-Serial chip (CP210x or CH340).

## 4. Baud Rate Mismatch

If you see 'garbage' characters in the console, your baud rate is likely incorrect. Try switching between **115200** and **9600** to see if communication stabilizes.
